context: The <a5_0><a5_1><a5_2>Lower<a5_1/> Rhine<a5_2/><a5_0/> flows through <b10_0><b11_0>North Rhine-Westphalia<b11_0/><b10_0/>. Its banks are usually heavily populated and industrialized, in particular the agglomerations Cologne, Düsseldorf and Ruhr area. Here the Rhine flows through the largest conurbation in Germany, the <a6_0><a6_1><a6_2>Rhine-Ruhr<a6_1/><a6_0/> region<a6_2/>. One of the most important cities in this region is <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a7_2>Duisburg<a7_2/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> with the largest river port in Europe (<a7_0><a7_1><b12_0>Duisport<b12_0/><a7_1/><a7_0/>). The region downstream of Duisburg is more agricultural. In Wesel, 30 km downstream of Duisburg, is located the western end of the second east-west shipping route, the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Wesel-Datteln Canal<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, which runs parallel to the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>Lippe<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Between Emmerich and Cleves the <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a8_0><a8_1><a8_2><b13_0>Emmerich Rhine Bridge<b13_0/><a8_2/><a8_1/><a8_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/>,<a3_2/> the longest suspension bridge in Germany, crosses the <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a9_0><a9_1><a9_2><b14_0>400 m<b14_0/><a9_2/><a9_1/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> wide<a9_0/> river. Near Krefeld, the river crosses the Uerdingen line, the line which separates the areas where Low German and High German are spoken.
